entities.description:
Scrooge is a central character in the narrative, primarily characterized by his miserly and unfeeling nature, often viewed negatively by others. Initially portrayed as a tight-fisted old man indifferent to the joys of life and the festive spirit, he expresses disdain for Christmas and social obligations, valuing business and wealth above all else. His contempt for kindness and community is particularly pronounced during the Christmas season, where he embodies a solitary and melancholic disposition, frequently showing unkindness to those around him.

However, Scrooge undergoes a significant transformation throughout the story, especially catalyzed by encounters with various spirits, including the Ghost of Christmas Past, the Ghost of Christmas Present, and the Ghost of Christmas Yet to Come. These supernatural visitations compel him to reflect on his past, present, and future, leading to a deep inner conflict and emotional turmoil. Through these reflections, he experiences moments of vulnerability and regret, grappling with the consequences of his actions and the impact of his miserly ways on himself and others.

As a result of this transformative journey, Scrooge ultimately embraces the spirit of Christmas, evolving from a cold-hearted and skeptical figure to one who embodies kindness, generosity, and joy. By the end of the narrative, he demonstrates a profound change of heart, actively seeking connection with others and engaging positively in the festive spirit. His character arc illustrates not only the contrast between his initial demeanor and his eventual joy and good intentions but also serves as a critique of greed and an affirmation of community and compassion during the Christmas season.
Master Scrooge, also known simply as Scrooge, is a character who experiences deep introspection and transformation throughout the story, reflecting on his past relationships and feelings of regret.

Ebenezer Scrooge is a central character who experiences a haunting by the Ghost of Jacob Marley, which foreshadows his journey of redemption.<SEP>Ebenezer Scrooge is a character who reflects on his past self and experiences nostalgia for his younger days.<SEP>Ebenezer Scrooge is the main character in A Christmas Carol, depicted as a miserly old man who undergoes a profound transformation.
Uncle Scrooge is a character who has a heartwarming transformation during Christmas, initially grumpy but becomes more open to joy and celebration.

Christmas is a festive holiday celebrated with themes of generosity, joy, family, and togetherness. It significantly impacts the characters within the narrative, particularly influencing Scrooge's character development. Throughout the story, Christmas symbolizes goodwill and reflection, serving as both a backdrop for events and a catalyst for change.

During this season, various traditions and celebrations occur, highlighting the importance of family gatherings and acts of kindness. Despite the joy and warmth associated with Christmas, Scrooge initially rejects these sentiments, opting for practicality and bitterness. His disdain for the holiday contrasts sharply with the feelings of joy and giving it represents, both for him and others, such as his nephew and the Cratchit family.

Ultimately, Christmas is portrayed as a time of reflection on one's life, encouraging themes of generosity and altering perceptions toward poverty. It is during this festive season that Scrooge's transformation begins, as he learns to embrace the values of kindness and community, marking a significant turning point in his character arc. Through the narrative, Christmas emerges as a powerful symbol of hope and change, illustrating the potential for redemption and the importance of love and togetherness.
Scrooge's Niece's Sisters are part of the family gathering, contributing to the discussions regarding Scrooge's character and their holiday sentiments.
Scrooge's Home is the location where Scrooge experiences eerie events and ultimately encounters Marley's Ghost, serving as a central setting in the narrative.
The Husband is a character who reflects on old friendships and speaks to his wife about Scrooge.

Joe is a character who appears to have a humorous and somewhat cynical view on life, expressing weaknesses in generosity and making comments on the dead man's possessions.<SEP>Joe is a character who interacts with other characters regarding their actions, highlighting the casual conversations surrounding Scrooge.
Scrooge's Former Self represents the younger version of Ebenezer Scrooge, reflecting on his past and interactions with his peers.
The Three Spirits that are foretold to visit Scrooge are pivotal in his transformation, representing lessons in his past, present, and future.
Darkness represents the emotional and social coldness associated with Scrooge's character and actions.
Winter weather is characterized by cold, harsh conditions that reflect Scrooge's personality and reinforce the story's gloomy mood.

Scrooge's Niece is depicted as a cheerful and pretty character who expresses her opinions earnestly and enjoys the merriment shared with her family.<SEP>Scrooge's niece is an engaging and musical character who participates in family games with enthusiasm.
Scrooge's eyes are described as being fixed and glazed, reflecting his skepticism and disbelief in the apparition before him.

Scrooge's Nephew is a jovial and cheerful character who embodies the spirit of Christmas. He enjoys laughter and seeks to share the joy of the holiday season with his uncle, Ebenezer Scrooge, despite Scrooge's disdain for Christmas. In contrast to Scrooge's miserable outlook on life, Scrooge's Nephew remains optimistic and actively includes Scrooge in family festivities. His lively demeanor and enthusiastic approach reflect his desire to encourage his uncle to embrace the holiday spirit, highlighting the warmth and joy that the season can bring.

Fezziwig is a character from Charles Dickens' "A Christmas Carol," recognized as Scrooge's former employer. He is fondly remembered for his jovial nature and the kindness he exhibited towards his employees, which starkly contrasts with Scrooge's later avarice. Fezziwig is particularly notable for hosting a cheerful domestic ball, embodying a festive spirit and generosity during Christmas Eve. His ability to make others happy highlights the warmth and joy of the Christmas season, underscoring the themes of merriment and kindness that are central to the story. As an old character with strong associations to Christmas festivities, Fezziwig represents the positive effects of compassion and community, serving as a pivotal influence in Scrooge's transformation.
Dick is mentioned as Scrooge's former self and companion, representing Scrooge's lost connection to joy and camaraderie.
The Bed serves as a significant setting for Scrooge's introspective moments, where he contemplates his experiences and the supernatural events occurring around him.

The Ghost is a significant supernatural figure in the narrative, serving as a guiding spirit that encourages Scrooge to confront his past experiences and emotions. This spirit shows Scrooge various scenes from his history, pushing him toward self-reflection and change. Representing not only Jacob Marley but also embodying the Spirit of Christmas, the Ghost conveys crucial moral lessons about remorse, the consequences of a life misused, and the importance of charity, compassion, family, and generosity. Through its interactions with Scrooge, the Ghost illuminates the impact of his past actions, ultimately guiding him toward personal transformation and a deeper understanding of the values he has neglected.

The Ghost is a significant supernatural entity that plays a crucial role in guiding Ebenezer Scrooge through his journey of reflection and redemption. Appearing as a figure of Scrooge's past, the Ghost represents his regrets and lost opportunities, serving as a poignant reminder of the life choices he has made. It acts as an apparition of Jacob Marley, conveying an essential message to Scrooge about the impacts of his actions on himself and those around him. Throughout their encounters, the Ghost highlights the consequences of Scrooge's behaviors, emphasizing the emotional connections tied to death and the joy experienced by others, which he has largely ignored. Additionally, the Ghost symbolizes the spirit of Christmas, aiming to spread joy and mirth while countering the darkness that has enveloped Scrooge's life.
Scrooge's nephew is a cheerful character who embodies laughter and good spirit, representing familial love and holiday joy.
The Phantom represents the spirit that guides Scrooge through scenes of his past and future, prompting his introspection and moral reckoning.
A Christmas Carol is a novella by Charles Dickens that tells the story of Ebenezer Scrooge and his transformation after being visited by three ghosts.

Jacob Marley is the deceased business partner of Ebenezer Scrooge, whose spirit plays a crucial role in Scrooge's journey of self-reflection and redemption. Appearing as a ghost, Jacob Marley warns Scrooge about the impending consequences of his selfish life choices, urging him to reconsider his current path. His ghostly visit reveals both the fate that awaits Scrooge if he continues his ways and the value of human life and connection. As a spectral figure, Jacob Marley connects Scrooge to the spirits of Christmas, facilitating his transformation by sharing profound lessons about empathy and the importance of relationships. Compelled to wander the earth, Marley's spirit seeks to impart wisdom and guidance, marking the beginning of Scrooge's path toward redemption.
The Bitter Night sets the stage for the supernatural occurrences as Scrooge prepares to settle in for the night.

Wealth refers to Scrooge's financial status, which is critiqued by his family for not being utilized to enhance their social interactions or traditions.<SEP>Wealth represents the focus on economic gain that has displaced emotional richness in Scrooge’s life, serving as a central theme in his character development.
Scrooge's Bedroom is the location where Ebenezer Scrooge experiences the supernatural visitations and reflections on his life choices.
The streets of London serve as the backdrop for Scrooge's journey, representing urban life and the social issues prevalent during the Victorian era.
Mr. Scrooge's nephew is a kind gentleman who shows compassion towards Bob Cratchit and his family, offering support.

Bob Cratchit is a character from Charles Dickens' "A Christmas Carol," serving as Ebenezer Scrooge's clerk. He is depicted as an overworked and underpaid employee who endures Scrooge's harsh treatment, yet remains devoted to his family. Despite his struggles to provide for his family, particularly in light of his son Tiny Tim's illness, Bob Cratchit maintains a generally positive demeanor and resilience, finding joy in simple festivities and the cherished unity of family.

As the father of the Cratchit family, Bob expresses profound affection and pride for his children, deeply valuing familial bonds. He looks forward to the Christmas holiday, which brings a sense of happiness and love into his home. Bob is a representation of the working class, embodying the challenges they face, particularly during times of family crisis, yet his character also reflects themes of humility, hope, and the importance of family values. He appreciates the festive meals prepared by his wife, showcasing his gratitude amidst difficulties. Overall, Bob Cratchit's character resonates with themes of struggle, joy, and familial devotion.
Scrooge and Marley is the name of the business jointly owned by Scrooge and his late partner, Marley.
The Christmas Holidays symbolize a time of joy, family, and togetherness, contrasted with Scrooge's initial loneliness and sorrow.
Businessmen in the text signify the wealth and social status that influence Scrooge's prior mindset, representing a certain disregard for human connection.

The City represents a bustling environment with busy thoroughfares filled with individuals and shops, especially noticeable during Christmas.<SEP>The City serves as a backdrop for various scenes where Scrooge experiences the realities and conversations of its inhabitants about wealth and death.
Tim is mentioned as a character in relation to Scrooge's reflections, hinting at deeper themes of family and loss.
Jacob is Scrooge's old partner, whose death influences Scrooge's reflections on life and relationships.
The Figure refers to a changing entity that Scrooge perceives, representing the fluidity of memories in his mind as he interacts with the Ghost.
Candle light signifies warmth and hope, contrasting with the cold and bare environment of Scrooge's memories.

Tiny Tim is a significant character in Charles Dickens' "A Christmas Carol," serving as the ill son of Bob and Mrs. Cratchit. He is characterized by his frail health and optimism, symbolizing hope, innocence, and the spirit of Christmas. Often noted for his famous line, "God bless Us, Every One!", Tiny Tim embodies the themes of compassion and the impact of economic hardship on families. His sweet singing voice and kind nature bring joy and warmth to the Cratchit household, making him a beloved figure among his family members.

As the youngest member of the Cratchit family, Tiny Tim's well-being is a constant concern for his parents, particularly his father, Bob Cratchit. He inspires feelings of kindness and reflection in those around him, playing a crucial role in Scrooge's journey towards understanding generosity and the true meaning of the Christmas spirit. Despite his physical challenges—using a crutch due to his frailty—Tiny Tim’s hopeful and warm presence is a source of inspiration, emphasizing the importance of family and the enduring spirit of love and generosity during the holiday season.

Fred is Scrooge's nephew who embodies warmth, familial love, and the joyous spirit of Christmas. He expresses admiration for Scrooge and initiates a toast in his honor during a Christmas gathering. Fred represents family warmth and festivities that starkly contrast with Scrooge's past behavior. During the festive season, he invites Scrooge to dinner, reflecting his desire to include his uncle in the celebrations and promote a sense of togetherness.
The Dead Man is a character whose body is treated carelessly by Joe and The Woman after his death, highlighting themes of avarice and lack of respect.

The City represents the urban environment where various scenes take place, highlighting the interactions and conversations of its inhabitants.<SEP>The city represents the environment in which Scrooge lives, characterized by both its social dynamics and economic struggles.
Wretched people represent the societal neglect and harsh conditions faced by those in the obscure part of town.
The Phantom Figure is a strange, ethereal visitor described with qualities that blend the traits of a child and an old man, symbolizing the melding of past and present.
Little Fan is Scrooge's younger sister, portrayed as cheerful and loving, eager to bring her brother home.

Topper is a jovial character in the story, known for his playful interactions during the Christmas gathering.<SEP>Topper is a member of Scrooge's Nephew's family who participates in the laughter and merriment during their gathering.
Belle is Scrooge's former love, mentioned as someone who could have brought joy to Scrooge's life.
The gentleman with the large chin is characterized by his yawning demeanor and delivers witty remarks regarding the deceased.
The red-faced gentleman is a character noted for having a pendulous excrescence on his nose and appears to participate in social discussions.
The Old Man's Lamp is a source of light in the scene, illuminating the actions and conversations surrounding the dead man's belongings, adding to the atmosphere of neglect and despair.
The neglected grave signifies the consequences of a life poorly lived, reflecting on Scrooge's potential future if he does not change.
Charity represents the act of giving help, often in the form of money or resources, which the Ghost emphasizes as an essential obligation of life.
Robin Crusoe is mentioned by Scrooge as part of a nostalgic memory, symbolizing adventure and longing for connection.
Dutch Tiles are a decorative feature in Scrooge's fireplace, illustrating biblical stories and adding to the setting's atmosphere.

Mrs. Cratchit is Bob Cratchit's wife and serves as a central figure in depicting the struggles and warmth of a working-class family during the holidays. She is a resilient and caring woman who manages the household and prepares meals despite the family's limited resources. Known for her disappointment towards Scrooge, she expresses strong feelings about his stinginess, reflecting the challenges faced by her family due to his meanness. 

Mrs. Cratchit is particularly devoted to her family's well-being, especially to her sickly son, Tiny Tim. She takes great pride in preparing the Christmas pudding, celebrating moments of happiness while demonstrating the nurturing aspect of the household. As a loving mother, she shows unwavering support and affection for her children, embodying the spirit of love and familial care amidst their hardships.

Martha Cratchit is another daughter of Bob Cratchit, symbolizing hope and the family values portrayed in the story.<SEP>Martha Cratchit is the daughter of Bob Cratchit, who arrives home late for Christmas dinner and is cherished by her family.<SEP>Martha is the Cratchits' daughter who works as an apprentice and looks forward to enjoying a holiday at home.
Stave One refers to the first chapter of the story, introducing the characters and setting the tone for the narrative.

Peter Cratchit is the son of Bob and Mrs. Cratchit, and he is depicted as a proud and excited young boy who eagerly dresses up for Christmas. As one of the older sons in the Cratchit family, Peter plays a significant role in helping to prepare for the holiday celebrations while also providing support to his younger brother Tiny Tim. He not only shows affection for his father during joyful moments but also expresses concern for his father's feelings and the family's well-being. Furthermore, Peter is portrayed as a thoughtful individual who contemplates his future employment opportunities, reflecting a mature consideration for his family's circumstances.

The Spirit refers to a ghostly figure that shows Scrooge various scenes, prompting him to reconsider his perspective on Christmas and humanity.<SEP>The Spirit represents a supernatural being that guides Scrooge through visions of his past, present, and future to instigate change.<SEP>The Spirit represents supernatural entities that guide Scrooge in reflecting on humanity and his life choices.
The Woman is a character who exhibits a practical and unfeeling attitude towards the dead man, humorously discussing the actions taken with his possessions.
The obscure part of town represents the destitution and moral decay Scrooge observes, contrasting sharply with his usual environment.
The Boy and Girl represent wretched conditions of poverty and are depicted as 'Ignorance' and 'Want', appealing to the humanity of Scrooge.

The Spirit embodies the essence of human consciousness and morality that urges individuals to act for the greater good during their lifetime.<SEP>The Spirit guides Scrooge through various experiences, teaching him important life lessons and revealing the suffering of the less fortunate.<SEP>The Spirit represents the benevolent force connected to Christmas that inspires joy and generosity.
The Flannel Bag contains money that Old Joe distributes, symbolizing the commercialization and exploitation of death.

Christmas-time is marked as a season for reflection and social gatherings, which contrasts with the themes of isolation and regret in Scrooge's life.<SEP>Christmas-time is referred to as a period associated with celebration, charity, and familial interactions.<SEP>Christmas-time serves as a backdrop for reflection and nostalgia, highlighting family and joyful times.
The gentlemen's trivial conversations during Christmas-time underscore their indifference to the spirit of the season and societal values.
Common Welfare encompasses the themes of charity, mercy, and the greater good which the Ghost emphasizes as the true purpose of human life.
Crowds of Fellow-Beings highlights the interconnectedness of humanity that the Ghost urges Scrooge to recognize and engage with.
The School is a significant location in Scrooge's past, representing a place of isolation and learning during his childhood.
The Servant is a minor character who offers hospitality to guests, illustrating class dynamics and social interactions of the time.

relations.description: Scrooge reflects on Fezziwig's ability to make people happy, contrasting it with his own hardened nature.<SEP>Scrooge's fond recollection of Fezziwig indicates a significant positive influence during his early career.

Fred and Scrooge have a complex familial relationship that evolves over the course of their interactions, particularly during the Christmas season. Fred expresses warm regards and a hopeful desire for Scrooge's change, reflecting the underlying bonds of family. Despite Scrooge's initial reluctance to participate in Christmas celebrations, Fred continues to invite him to join the festivities. Ultimately, after experiencing a personal transformation, Scrooge rejects his previous dismissive attitude and accepts Fred's invitation to Christmas dinner. This shift marks a significant change in Scrooge's perspective on family and the spirit of Christmas, showcasing his eagerness to reconnect with his nephew.

Scrooge's Niece expresses her disapproval of Scrooge's attitude towards Christmas, reflecting the family's contrasting views of the holiday.<SEP>Scrooge's niece's joyful participation in games brings a lightness to Scrooge's demeanor, illustrating familial bonds.

Joe's irreverent comments about the dead man contrast sharply with Scrooge's emotional turmoil, highlighting the difference in their perspectives.<SEP>Scrooge's interactions with Joe reflect his disdain for the festive spirit that others find humorous and uplifting.
Scrooge's horror and reflection on the Dead Man's fate trigger a moment of self-awareness and contemplation of his own life choices.

As Scrooge moves through the City, he witnesses the lives of others and the impact of wealth and selfishness on society.<SEP>Scrooge's transformation affects how he interacts with the city, as he becomes more considerate towards its inhabitants and challenges.
Scrooge's observations of the wretched people highlight his growing awareness of the negative effects of wealth and indifference.
Scrooge encounters the Phantom Figure, which embodies an amalgamation of childhood innocence and elder wisdom, leading him to ponder his past and the essence of time.
Scrooge's relationship with Little Fan reflects familial love and joy, contrasting with his later life experiences.
Scrooge observes Topper's playful behavior during the games, reflecting on his own past attitudes towards merriment.

Belle reflects on her past relationship with Scrooge, indicating the emotional impact he has had on her life.<SEP>Scrooge reflects on his past relationship with Belle, showing regret and longing for what might have been.
The Phantom guides Scrooge, prompting him to assess his life decisions and their consequences in relation to social values.
The gentleman with the large chin's remarks capture Scrooge's reflection on social attitudes towards death and connection.
Scrooge observes the red-faced gentleman's humor about the funeral, highlighting the lack of respect for life among characters.
The dim light from the Old Man's Lamp casts shadows on Scrooge, enhancing his feelings of horror and reflection about life and death.
The neglected grave serves as a pivotal moment for Scrooge, showcasing the dire consequences of a life without love and humanity.
Winter weather reflects Scrooge's personality traits, portraying him as cold and unapproachable, akin to the harsh elements around him.
Scrooge's reflections are influenced by the memory of Jacob, as he contemplates the impact of their relationship after Jacob's death.
Scrooge's reflection on his life brings him to consider the importance of charity, which the Ghost insists was a crucial aspect of living well.
Scrooge's reflections occur in bed where he grapples with the consequences of his actions and the haunting of the Ghosts.
Scrooge recalls Robin Crusoe during a moment of remembrance, emphasizing his yearning for connection.
Dick represents a part of Scrooge's past, highlighting the emotional connections that Scrooge has lost.
The Dutch Tiles in Scrooge’s fireplace serve to attract his thoughts, reflecting his internal struggles while he broods over his lonely situation.
Bob Cratchit works under Ebenezer Scrooge, highlighting the exploitation of the working class.

Bob Cratchit is a devoted father to Tiny Tim, and their relationship embodies the hardships and emotional dynamics of the Cratchit family. As they navigate significant financial difficulties, Bob's protective and affectionate demeanor towards Tiny Tim is evident. He expresses deep concern for his son's health and well-being, often holding Tiny Tim's hand and showcasing the love that drives his efforts to care for his family during the challenging holiday season.

Tiny Tim, as Bob's son, symbolizes innocence and hope amid the family's struggles. His hopeful spirit and presence during Christmas serve as the emotional core of the Cratchit family, influencing Bob's feelings of happiness and determination to maintain joy despite their circumstances. Together, they represent the love and resilience found in the relationship between a father and son, highlighting the emotional stakes tied to health and family happiness. Bob Cratchit's heartfelt connection to Tiny Tim encapsulates the profound struggles and warmth characterizing their life together.

Bob Cratchit and Mrs. Cratchit exemplify a loving partnership, working collaboratively to create a joyful Christmas environment for their children, while also facing the challenges of working-class life. They emphasize the importance of teamwork in family matters and household management, supporting each other in caring for their family. Together, they navigate tough times, highlighting their unity during Christmas and their resilience in adversity. Through their efforts, they embody the struggles and joys of family life, showcasing a strong bond that is essential for their family's well-being.

Bob Cratchit shows affection and concern for Martha when she arrives home, demonstrating the family’s bond.<SEP>Martha's arrival and her playful energy represent the joy and liveliness that enrich the Cratchit family's Christmas celebration, which Bob cherishes.
Stave One sets the stage for understanding the significance of Christmas in the transformation of Scrooge's character.

Bob Cratchit shares affectionate moments with Peter, fostering a caring environment at home.<SEP>Peter engages in conversations with Bob, expressing concern for the family and demonstrating generational solidarity.<SEP>Peter's excitement about dressing well for Christmas reflects the hope and ambition of the younger generation in the Cratchit family.
Scrooge's former self is reflected in Scrooge's memories, highlighting the changes he has undergone through time.
The Spirit points to the City, showing the hustle and bustle of life, contrasting with the moral lessons being imparted to Scrooge.
Peter and Martha Cratchit are siblings who share a familial bond and aspirations for their futures.
Joe and The Woman share a conversation that reveals their attitudes towards the dead man and the after-effects of his avarice.
The Phantom directs Scrooge's attention to the grim reality of life in the Obscure Part of the Town, highlighting the consequences of his past choices.
The Spirit reveals the Boy and Girl as embodiments of Ignorance and Want, emphasizing societal issues that need addressing.
The Woman's interaction with the Flannel Bag underscores her pragmatic approach to the dead man's demise, further accentuating her callousness.
The gentlemen's trivial conversations during Christmas-time underscore their indifference to the spirit of the season and societal values.
The two gentlemen engage in a conversation about someone’s money and funeral, indicating their shared social environment.
The imperative to recognize crowds of fellow-beings underscores the connection to the common welfare, which should drive human actions.
The Servant reflects the class dynamics of the time, where he serves the more privileged, such as Scrooge, underscoring social stratification.

Christmas symbolizes the hope and joy that Scrooge longs for but has lost in his life. Throughout his story, Scrooge initially expresses disdain for Christmas, viewing it as a time of burden rather than a celebration. His cold demeanor and disdain serve as a stark contrast to the warmth and values associated with the holiday, emphasizing the central theme of his character. However, as he reflects on Christmas, he experiences a sense of regret and nostalgia, which highlights his complex feelings towards the holiday.

Scrooge's character transformation is significantly influenced by the spirit of Christmas, which catalyzes a shift towards kindness and compassion. He ultimately pledges to honor Christmas in his life, marking a pivotal change in his attitude. This transformation involves recognizing the importance of kindness, generosity, and community during the holiday season, leading to acts of kindness and generosity that were once foreign to him.

As a result, Scrooge's attitude towards Christmas radically evolves, illustrating his development from a bitter misanthrope to a character who embodies the true spirit of the holiday. The journey from disdain to joy reflects the profound impact that the Christmas spirit has on him, highlighting the enduring message of goodwill that the holiday represents.

Bob Cratchit works for Scrooge, representing a complex and often strained employee-employer relationship. Despite Scrooge's harsh nature and disdainful treatment, Bob feels a sense of gratitude, which highlights the difficult circumstances faced by workers during that period. Bob's struggles to provide for his family underscore the broader impact of Scrooge's past actions on the poor and emphasize the critical importance of compassion.

However, Scrooge's oppressive treatment of Bob shows a stark contrast to his behavior after his transformation. As Scrooge undergoes a significant change of heart, he goes from treating Bob with disdain to raising his salary and offering to assist his family. This shift is also exemplified by Scrooge's decision to send a large turkey to the Cratchit household, demonstrating his newfound generosity and a deeper connection to Bob's family.

Scrooge celebrates Christmas Day with newfound joy, marking his transformation and intentions to make amends.<SEP>Scrooge's character clashes with the spirit of Christmas, which is celebrated joyfully by others but rejected by him.

Scrooge expresses concern for Tiny Tim's well-being, reflecting his growth and newfound empathy for the needy.<SEP>Scrooge reflects on Tiny Tim's situation, which motivates his desire to help others and show compassion.

Scrooge interacts with the Spirit in a quest for understanding his past and its implications for his future.<SEP>The Spirit guides Scrooge through various scenes, helping him to reflect on his life and the meaning of Christmas.

Jacob Marley is Scrooge's former business partner who has returned as a ghost to communicate important truths about life and death. His spectral presence serves as a pivotal force in prompting Scrooge to confront his life choices and reflect on the need for change. Marley is the reason for Scrooge's encounters with the spirits, having sent them as a warning about the consequences of his past mistakes. During his ghostly visit, Marley warns Scrooge to amend his ways before it is too late, underscoring the message of redemption and the importance of living with purpose. Scrooge's recollection of his connection with Jacob Marley heightens the emotional weight of Marley's message, significantly influencing Scrooge's transformation and representing the possibilities of redemption linked to his own past.
Mrs. Cratchit's disdain for Scrooge illustrates the negative impact of his stinginess on the Cratchit family.

Scrooge and the Ghost are engaged in a critical dialogue that highlights Scrooge's internal struggle with his past actions and the impact of those choices on his spirit. The Ghost plays a crucial role in guiding Scrooge through his memories, which is pivotal to Scrooge's self-realization and character development. Through these reflections, the Ghost influences Scrooge's understanding of his past, particularly showcasing his younger self, which prompts significant emotional growth. Additionally, the Ghost emphasizes reflections on the spirit of Christmas, instilling in Scrooge the importance of kindness and community. Ultimately, these interactions lead Scrooge toward a deeper awareness of his life choices and the possibility for redemption.
The Ghost of Christmas Present guides Scrooge, offering him insights into generosity and compassion associated with the Christmas spirit.
Scrooge's horror at the scene involving Death prompts a moment of realization about his own life choices and the fate awaiting him.

Scrooge and his nephew share a contentious relationship primarily centered around the meaning of Christmas. While Scrooge staunchly rejects the festive spirit and any associated celebrations, his nephew remains optimistic and eager to engage him in cheerful conversation about the holiday. Despite receiving negativity from Scrooge, Scrooge's nephew feels a sense of pity for his uncle's distaste for Christmas and continues to invite him to various celebrations, promoting joy and familial togetherness. The nephew's unwavering hope and positivity highlight the strength of their familial bonds, as he encourages Scrooge to embrace the spirit of Christmas, demonstrating the affection and care he holds for his uncle, even in the face of rejection.

The Ghost guides Scrooge and helps him confront his past, leading him on a journey through his memories and shaping his character development.<SEP>The Ghost of Christmas Past serves as a guide for Scrooge, helping him revisit crucial moments from his life that affect his current behavior.<SEP>The Spirit guides Scrooge to reflect on his past, helping him confront his memories and feelings of neglect.

Marley's Ghost acts as a precursor to Scrooge's encounters with the Phantom Figure, setting the stage for Scrooge's transformation and reflections on his past.<SEP>Scrooge encounters Marley's Ghost in his home, which signifies an important turning point in his character arc and the narrative.<SEP>Scrooge's interactions with Marley's Ghost provoke him to reconsider his life choices and beliefs about time and reality.

Scrooge is guided by The Ghost, who reveals the profound effects of death, serving as a metaphorical guide that helps him to understand the implications of his life choices. Throughout this encounter, Scrooge is confronted by the spirit of Jacob Marley, which challenges his long-held beliefs and perceptions about life and relationships. The Ghost illustrates the significant impact of Scrooge's actions on the lives of others, playing a crucial role in his potential transformation. This spectral presence encourages Scrooge to reconsider his cold disposition towards Christmas and other people, while also acting as a reminder of his past and the consequences of his choices. Overall, The Ghost serves to provoke deep introspection in Scrooge, aiming to guide him towards a more compassionate and understanding perspective.

Scrooge and Marley were business partners, and Marley's death significantly impacts Scrooge's character development.<SEP>Scrooge's encounter with Marley’s ghost serves as a pivotal moment prompting his reflection on life choices and morality.
The Spirit serves as a catalyst for Scrooge's transformation by showing him visions of his life and the consequences of his actions.

relations.description: The Ghost of Christmas Yet to Come reveals to Scrooge the consequences of his actions, motivating a profound change in him.
Scrooge's visit to the Obscure Part of the Town reveals his growing awareness of societal neglect and moral decay.
Scrooge displays disdain for Christmas Eve, accentuating his character's miserly attitude and resistance to joy.

Scrooge and Dick Wilkins shared a close working relationship, indicating a sense of companionship during their apprenticeship.<SEP>Scrooge recalls his relationship with Dick Wilkins fondly, which highlights camaraderie and highlights the warmth of past friendships.
Scrooge demonstrates his refusal to help the Gentleman with charitable contributions, showcasing his selfishness and lack of empathy.
Scrooge's character and experiences are framed within the context of London, highlighting societal issues and class disparities.
Scrooge reflects on the significance of community gatherings in churches during Christmas, highlighting the spiritual aspect of the holiday.
Scrooge observes the playful banter between Topper and the plump sister, reflecting on his own experiences with family joy during Christmas.

The Ghost guides Scrooge through his interactions with family, emphasizing the importance of joy and connection during Christmas.<SEP>The Ghost of Christmas Present exposes Scrooge to the joy and generosity present in the world today.
The Spirit guides Scrooge through his memories, facilitating his emotional journey and introspection.
Scrooge is confronted by the Spirit of Marley, who seeks to explain the importance of his past actions and beliefs.
The solitary child left at the school represents a younger version of Scrooge, highlighting themes of neglect and a yearning for the past.
Scrooge manages the Counting-House where he works, reflecting his miserly practices in managing finances and employees.

'Spirit! are they yours?' Scrooge could say no more.

'They are Man's,' said the Spirit, looking down upon them. 'And they
cling to me, appealing from their fathers. This boy is Ignorance. This
girl is Want. Beware of them both, and all of their degree, but most of
all beware this boy, for on his brow I see that written which is Doom,
unless the writing be erased. Deny it!' cried the Spirit, stretching out
his hand towards the city. 'Slander those who tell it ye! Admit it for
your factious purposes, and make it worse! And bide the end!'

'Have they no refuge or resource?' cried Scrooge.

'Are there no prisons?' said the Spirit, turning on him for the last
time with his own words. 'Are there no workhouses?'

The bell struck Twelve.

Scrooge looked about him for the Ghost, and saw it not. As the last
stroke ceased to vibrate, he remembered the prediction of old Jacob
Marley, and, lifting up his eyes, beheld a solemn Phantom, draped and
hooded, coming like a mist along the ground towards him.


STAVE FOUR




THE LAST OF THE SPIRITS


The Phantom slowly, gravely, silently approached. When it came near him,
Scrooge bent down upon his knee; for in the very air through which this
Spirit moved it seemed to scatter gloom and mystery.

It was shrouded in a deep black garment, which concealed its head, its
face, its form, and left nothing of it visible, save one outstretched
hand. But for this, it would have been difficult to detach its figure
from the night, and separate it from the darkness by which it was
surrounded.

He felt that it was tall and stately when it came beside him, and that
its mysterious presence filled him with a solemn dread. He knew no more,
for the Spirit neither spoke nor moved.

'I am in the presence of the Ghost of Christmas Yet to Come?' said
Scrooge.

The Spirit answered not, but pointed onward with its hand.

'You are about to show me shadows of the things that have not happened,
but will happen in the time before us,' Scrooge pursued. 'Is that so,
Spirit?'

The upper portion of the garment was contracted for an instant in its
folds, as if the Spirit had inclined its head. That was the only answer
he received.

Although well used to ghostly company by this time, Scrooge feared the
silent shape so much that his legs trembled beneath him, and he found
that he could hardly stand when he prepared to follow it. The Spirit
paused a moment, as observing his condition, and giving him time to
recover.

But Scrooge was all the worse for this. It thrilled him with a vague,
uncertain horror to know that, behind the dusky shroud, there were
ghostly eyes intently fixed upon him, while he, though he stretched his
own to the utmost, could see nothing but a spectral hand and one great
heap of black.

'Ghost of the Future!' he exclaimed, 'I fear you more than any spectre
I have seen. But as I know your purpose is to do me good, and as I hope
to live to be another man from what I was, I am prepared to bear your
company, and do it with a thankful heart. Will you not speak to me?'

It gave him no reply. The hand was pointed straight before them.

'Lead on!' said Scrooge. 'Lead on! The night is waning fast, and it is
precious time to me, I know. Lead on, Spirit!'

The Phantom moved away as it had come towards him. Scrooge followed in
the shadow of its dress, which bore him up, he thought, and carried him
along.

They scarcely seemed to enter the City; for the City rather seemed to
spring up about them, and encompass them of its own act. But there they
were in the heart of it; on 'Change, amongst the merchants, who hurried
up and down, and chinked the money in their pockets, and conversed in
groups, and looked at their watches, and trifled thoughtfully with their
great gold seals, and so forth, as Scrooge had seen them often.

The Spirit stopped beside one little knot of business men. Observing
that the hand was pointed to them, Scrooge advanced to listen to their
talk.

'No,' said a great fat man with a monstrous chin, 'I don't know much
about it either way. I only know he's dead.'

'When did he die?' inquired another.

'Last night, I believe.'

'Why, what was the matter with him?' asked a third, taking a vast
quantity of snuff out of a very large snuff-box. 'I thought he'd never
die.'

'God knows,' said the first, with a yawn.

'What has he done with his money?' asked a red-faced gentleman with a
pendulous excrescence on the end of his nose, that shook like the gills
of a turkey-cock.

'I haven't heard,' said the man with the large chin, yawning again.
'Left it to his company, perhaps. He hasn't left it to _me_. That's all
I know.'

This pleasantry was received with a general

hands,
and splitting with a laugh. 'He shan't know who sends it. It's twice the
size of Tiny Tim. Joe Miller never made such a joke as sending it to
Bob's will be!'

The hand in which he wrote the address was not a steady one; but write
it he did, somehow, and went downstairs to open the street-door, ready
for the coming of the poulterer's man. As he stood there, waiting his
arrival, the knocker caught his eye.

'I shall love it as long as I live!' cried Scrooge, patting it with his
hand. 'I scarcely ever looked at it before. What an honest expression it
has in its face! It's a wonderful knocker!--Here's the turkey. Hallo!
Whoop! How are you! Merry Christmas!'

It _was_ a turkey! He never could have stood upon his legs, that bird.
He would have snapped 'em short off in a minute, like sticks of
sealing-wax.

'Why, it's impossible to carry that to Camden Town,' said Scrooge. 'You
must have a cab.'

The chuckle with which he said this, and the chuckle with which he paid
for the turkey, and the chuckle with which he paid for the cab, and the
chuckle with which he recompensed the boy, were only to be exceeded by
the chuckle with which he sat down breathless in his chair again, and
chuckled till he cried.

Shaving was not an easy task, for his hand continued to shake very much;
and shaving requires attention, even when you don't dance while you are
at it. But if he had cut the end of his nose off, he would have put a
piece of sticking-plaster over it, and been quite satisfied.

He dressed himself 'all in his best,' and at last got out into the
streets. The people were by this time pouring forth, as he had seen them
with the Ghost of Christmas Present; and, walking with his hands behind
him, Scrooge regarded every one with a delighted smile. He looked so
irresistibly pleasant, in a word, that three or four good-humoured
fellows said, 'Good-morning, sir! A merry Christmas to you!' And Scrooge
said often afterwards that, of all the blithe sounds he had ever heard,
those were the blithest in his ears.

He had not gone far when, coming on towards him, he beheld the portly
gentleman who had walked into his counting-house the day before, and
said, 'Scrooge and Marley's, I believe?' It sent a pang across his heart
to think how this old gentleman would look upon him when they met; but
he knew what path lay straight before him, and he took it.

'My dear sir,' said Scrooge, quickening his pace, and taking the old
gentleman by both his hands, 'how do you do? I hope you succeeded
yesterday. It was very kind of you. A merry Christmas to you, sir!'

'Mr. Scrooge?'

'Yes,' said Scrooge. 'That is my name, and I fear it may not be pleasant
to you. Allow me to ask your pardon. And will you have the goodness----'
Here Scrooge whispered in his ear.

'Lord bless me!' cried the gentleman, as if his breath were taken away.
'My dear Mr. Scrooge, are you serious?'

'If you please,' said Scrooge. 'Not a farthing less. A great many
back-payments are included in it, I assure you. Will you do me that
favour?'

'My dear sir,' said the other, shaking hands with him, 'I don't know
what to say to such munifi----'

'Don't say anything, please,' retorted Scrooge. 'Come and see me. Will
you come and see me?'

'I will!' cried the old gentleman. And it was clear he meant to do it.

'Thankee,' said Scrooge. 'I am much obliged to you. I thank you fifty
times. Bless you!'

He went to church, and walked about the streets, and watched the people
hurrying to and fro, and patted the children on the head, and questioned
beggars, and looked down into the kitchens of houses, and up to the
windows; and found that everything could yield him pleasure. He had
never dreamed that any walk--that anything--could give him so much
happiness. In the afternoon he turned his steps towards his nephew's
house.

He passed the door a dozen times before he had the courage to go up and
knock. But he made a dash and did it.

'Is your master at home, my dear?' said Scrooge to the girl. 'Nice girl!
Very.'

'Yes, sir.'

'Where is he, my love?' said Scrooge.

'He's in the dining-room, sir, along with mistress. I'll show you
upstairs, if you please.'

'Thankee. He knows me,' said Scrooge, with his hand already on the
dining-room lock. 'I'll go in here, my dear.'

He turned it gently, and sidled his face in round the door. They were
looking at the table (which was spread out in great array); for these
young housekeepers are always nervous on such points, and like to see
that everything is right.

'Fred!' said Scrooge.

Dear heart alive, how his niece by marriage started! Scrooge had
forgotten,

'And I know,' said Bob, 'I know, my dears, that when we recollect how

'No, never, father!' they all cried again.

'I am very happy,' said little Bob, 'I am very happy!'

Mrs. Cratchit kissed him, his daughters kissed him, the two young
Cratchits kissed him, and Peter and himself shook hands. Spirit of Tiny
Tim, thy childish essence was from God!

'Spectre,' said Scrooge, 'something informs me that our parting moment
is at hand. I know it but I know not how. Tell me what man that was whom
we saw lying dead?'

The Ghost of Christmas Yet to Come conveyed him, as before--though at a
different time, he thought: indeed there seemed no order in these latter
visions, save that they were in the Future--into the resorts of business
men, but showed him not himself. Indeed, the Spirit did not stay for
anything, but went straight on, as to the end just now desired, until
besought by Scrooge to tarry for a moment.

'This court,' said Scrooge, 'through which we hurry now, is where my
place of occupation is, and has been for a length of time. I see the
house. Let me behold what I shall be in days to come.'

The Spirit stopped; the hand was pointed elsewhere.

'The house is yonder,' Scrooge exclaimed. 'Why do you point away?'

The inexorable finger underwent no change.

Scrooge hastened to the window of his office, and looked in. It was an
office still, but not his. The furniture was not the same, and the
figure in the chair was not himself. The Phantom pointed as before.

He joined it once again, and, wondering why and whither he had gone,
accompanied it until they reached an iron gate. He paused to look round
before entering.

A churchyard. Here, then, the wretched man, whose name he had now to
learn, lay underneath the ground. It was a worthy place. Walled in by
houses; overrun by grass and weeds, the growth of vegetation's death,
not life; choked up with too much burying; fat with repleted appetite. A
worthy place!

The Spirit stood among the graves, and pointed down to One. He advanced
towards it trembling. The Phantom was exactly as it had been, but he
dreaded that he saw new meaning in its solemn shape.

'Before I draw nearer to that stone to which you point,' said Scrooge,
'answer me one question. Are these the shadows of the things that Will
be, or are they shadows of the things that May be only?'

Still the Ghost pointed downward to the grave by which it stood.

'Men's courses will foreshadow certain ends, to which, if persevered in,
they must lead,' said Scrooge. 'But if the courses be departed from, the
ends will change. Say it is thus with what you show me!'

The Spirit was immovable as ever.

Scrooge crept towards it, trembling as he went; and, following the
finger, read upon the stone of the neglected grave his own name,
EBENEZER SCROOGE.

'Am I that man who lay upon the bed?' he cried upon his knees.

The finger pointed from the grave to him, and back again.

'No, Spirit! Oh no, no!'

The finger still was there.

'Spirit!' he cried, tight clutching at its robe, 'hear me! I am not the
man I was. I will not be the man I must have been but for this
intercourse. Why show me this, if I am past all hope?'

For the first time the hand appeared to shake.

'Good Spirit,' he pursued, as down upon the ground he fell before it,
'your nature intercedes for me, and pities me. Assure me that I yet may
change these shadows you have shown me by an altered life?'

The kind hand trembled.

'I will honour Christmas in my heart, and try to keep it all the year. I
will live in the Past, the Present, and the Future. The Spirits of all
Three shall strive within me. I will not shut out the lessons that they
teach. Oh, tell me I may sponge away the writing on this stone!'

In his agony he caught the spectral hand. It sought to free itself, but
he was strong in his entreaty, and detained it. The Spirit stronger yet,
repulsed him.

Holding up his hands in a last prayer to have his fate reversed, he saw
an alteration in the Phantom's hood and dress. It shrunk, collapsed, and
dwindled down into a bedpost.


STAVE FIVE


[Illustration]




THE END OF IT


Yes! and the bedpost was his own. The bed was his own, the room was his
own. Best and happiest of all, the Time before him was his own, to make
amends in!

'I will live in the Past, the Present, and the Future!' Scrooge repeated
as he scrambled out of bed. 'The Spirits of all Three shall strive
within me. O Jacob Marley! Heaven and the Christmas Time be praised for
this! I say it on my knees, old Jacob; on my knees!'

toys and presents. Then the shouting and the struggling, and the
onslaught that was made on the defenceless porter! The scaling him, with
chairs for ladders, to dive into his pockets, despoil him of
brown-paper parcels, hold on tight by his cravat, hug him round his
neck, pummel his back, and kick his legs in irrepressible affection! The
shouts of wonder and delight with which the development of every package
was received! The terrible announcement that the baby had been taken in
the act of putting a doll's frying pan into his mouth, and was more than
suspected of having swallowed a fictitious turkey, glued on a wooden
platter! The immense relief of finding this a false alarm! The joy, and
gratitude, and ecstasy! They are all indescribable alike. It is enough
that, by degrees, the children and their emotions got out of the
parlour, and, by one stair at a time, up to the top of the house, where
they went to bed, and so subsided.

And now Scrooge looked on more attentively than ever, when the master of
the house, having his daughter leaning fondly on him, sat down with her
and her mother at his own fireside; and when he thought that such
another creature, quite as graceful and as full of promise, might have
called him father, and been a spring-time in the haggard winter of his
life, his sight grew very dim indeed.

'Belle,' said the husband, turning to his wife with a smile, 'I saw an
old friend of yours this afternoon.'

'Who was it?'

'Guess!'

'How can I? Tut, don't I know?' she added in the same breath, laughing
as he laughed. 'Mr. Scrooge.'

'Mr. Scrooge it was. I passed his office window; and as it was not shut
up, and he had a candle inside, I could scarcely help seeing him. His
partner lies upon the point of death, I hear; and there he sat alone.
Quite alone in the world, I do believe.'

'Spirit!' said Scrooge in a broken voice, 'remove me from this place.'

'I told you these were shadows of the things that have been,' said the
Ghost. 'That they are what they are do not blame me!'

'Remove me!' Scrooge exclaimed, 'I cannot bear it!'

He turned upon the Ghost, and seeing that it looked upon him with a
face, in which in some strange way there were fragments of all the faces
it had shown him, wrestled with it.

'Leave me! Take me back. Haunt me no longer!'

In the struggle, if that can be called a struggle in which the Ghost
with no visible resistance on its own part was undisturbed by any effort
of its adversary, Scrooge observed that its light was burning high and
bright; and dimly connecting that with its influence over him, he seized
the extinguisher-cap, and by a sudden action pressed it down upon its
head.

[Illustration: _Laden with Christmas toys and presents_]

The Spirit dropped beneath it, so that the extinguisher covered its
whole form; but though Scrooge pressed it down with all his force, he
could not hide the light, which streamed from under it, in an unbroken
flood upon the ground.

He was conscious of being exhausted, and overcome by an irresistible
drowsiness; and, further, of being in his own bedroom. He gave the cap a
parting squeeze, in which his hand relaxed; and had barely time to reel
to bed, before he sank into a heavy sleep.

[Illustration]


STAVE THREE


[Illustration]




THE SECOND OF THE THREE SPIRITS


Awaking in the middle of a prodigiously tough snore, and sitting up in
bed to get his thoughts together, Scrooge had no occasion to be told
that the bell was again upon the stroke of One. He felt that he was
restored to consciousness in the right nick of time, for the especial
purpose of holding a conference with the second messenger despatched to
him through Jacob Marley's intervention. But finding that he turned
uncomfortably cold when he began to wonder which of his curtains this
new spectre would draw back, he put them every one aside with his own
hands, and, lying down again, established a sharp look-out all round the
bed. For he wished to challenge the Spirit on the moment of its
appearance, and did not wish to be taken by surprise and made nervous.

Gentlemen of the free-and-easy sort, who plume themselves on being
acquainted with a move or two, and being usually equal to the time of
day, express the wide range of their capacity for adventure by observing
that they are good for anything from pitch-and-toss to manslaughter;
between which opposite extremes, no doubt, there lies a tolerably wide
and comprehensive range of subjects. Without venturing for Scrooge quite
as hardily as this, I don't mind calling on you to believe that he was
ready for a good broad field of strange appearances, and that nothing
between a baby and a rhinoceros would have astonished him very much.

Now, being prepared for almost anything, he was not by any means
prepared for nothing; and consequently, when the bell struck One, and no
shape appeared, he was taken with a violent fit of trembling. Five

be terrified with the sight of Marley's pigtail sticking out into the
hall. But there was nothing on the back of the door, except the screws
and nuts that held the knocker on, so he said, 'Pooh, pooh!' and closed
it with a bang.

The sound resounded through the house like thunder. Every room above,
and every cask in the wine-merchant's cellars below, appeared to have a
separate peal of echoes of its own. Scrooge was not a man to be
frightened by echoes. He fastened the door, and walked across the hall,
and up the stairs: slowly, too: trimming his candle as he went.

You may talk vaguely about driving a coach and six up a good old flight
of stairs, or through a bad young Act of Parliament; but I mean to say
you might have got a hearse up that staircase, and taken it broadwise,
with the splinter-bar towards the wall, and the door towards the
balustrades: and done it easy. There was plenty of width for that, and
room to spare; which is perhaps the reason why Scrooge thought he saw a
locomotive hearse going on before him in the gloom. Half-a-dozen
gas-lamps out of the street wouldn't have lighted the entry too well, so
you may suppose that it was pretty dark with Scrooge's dip.

Up Scrooge went, not caring a button for that. Darkness is cheap, and
Scrooge liked it. But, before he shut his heavy door, he walked through
his rooms to see that all was right. He had just enough recollection of
the face to desire to do that.

Sitting-room, bedroom, lumber-room. All as they should be. Nobody under
the table, nobody under the sofa; a small fire in the grate; spoon and
basin ready; and the little saucepan of gruel (Scrooge had a cold in his
head) upon the hob. Nobody under the bed; nobody in the closet; nobody
in his dressing-gown, which was hanging up in a suspicious attitude
against the wall. Lumber-room as usual. Old fire-guard, old shoes, two
fish baskets, washing-stand on three legs, and a poker.

[Illustration: _Nobody under the bed; nobody in the closet; nobody in
his dressing-gown, which was hanging up in a suspicious attitude against
the wall_]

Quite satisfied, he closed his door, and locked himself in; double
locked himself in, which was not his custom. Thus secured against
surprise, he took off his cravat; put on his dressing-gown and slippers,
and his nightcap; and sat down before the fire to take his gruel.

It was a very low fire indeed; nothing on such a bitter night. He was
obliged to sit close to it, and brood over it, before he could extract
the least sensation of warmth from such a handful of fuel. The fireplace
was an old one, built by some Dutch merchant long ago, and paved all
round with quaint Dutch tiles, designed to illustrate the Scriptures.
There were Cains and Abels, Pharaoh's daughters, Queens of Sheba,
Angelic messengers descending through the air on clouds like
feather-beds, Abrahams, Belshazzars, Apostles putting off to sea in
butter-boats, hundreds of figures to attract his thoughts; and yet that
face of Marley, seven years dead, came like the ancient Prophet's rod,
and swallowed up the whole. If each smooth tile had been a blank at
first, with power to shape some picture on its surface from the
disjointed fragments of his thoughts, there would have been a copy of
old Marley's head on every one.

'Humbug!' said Scrooge; and walked across the room.

After several turns he sat down again. As he threw his head back in the
chair, his glance happened to rest upon a bell, a disused bell, that
hung in the room, and communicated, for some purpose now forgotten, with
a chamber in the highest storey of the building. It was with great
astonishment, and with a strange, inexplicable dread, that, as he
looked, he saw this bell begin to swing. It swung so softly in the
outset that it scarcely made a sound; but soon it rang out loudly, and
so did every bell in the house.

This might have lasted half a minute, or a minute, but it seemed an
hour. The bells ceased, as they had begun, together. They were succeeded
by a clanking noise deep down below as if some person were dragging a
heavy chain over the casks in the wine-merchant's cellar. Scrooge then
remembered to have heard that ghosts in haunted houses were described as
dragging chains.

The cellar door flew open with a booming sound, and then he heard the
noise much louder on the floors below; then coming up the stairs; then
coming straight towards his door.

'It's humbug still!' said Scrooge. 'I won't believe it.'

His colour changed, though, when, without a pause, it came on through
the heavy door and passed into the room before his eyes. Upon its coming
in, the dying flame leaped up, as though it cried, 'I know him! Marley's
Ghost!' and fell again.

The same face: the very same. Marley in his pigtail, usual waistcoat,
tights, and boots; the tassels on the latter bristling

other at the door, crashing their wicker baskets
wildly, and left their purchases upon the counter, and came running
back to fetch them, and committed hundreds of the like mistakes, in the
best humour possible; while the grocer and his people were so frank and
fresh, that the polished hearts with which they fastened their aprons
behind might have been their own, worn outside for general inspection,
and for Christmas daws to peck at if they chose.

But soon the steeples called good people all to church and chapel, and
away they came, flocking through the streets in their best clothes and
with their gayest faces. And at the same time there emerged, from scores
of by-streets, lanes, and nameless turnings, innumerable people,
carrying their dinners to the bakers' shops. The sight of these poor
revellers appeared to interest the Spirit very much, for he stood with
Scrooge beside him in a baker's doorway, and, taking off the covers as
their bearers passed, sprinkled incense on their dinners from his torch.
And it was a very uncommon kind of torch, for once or twice, when there
were angry words between some dinner-carriers who had jostled each
other, he shed a few drops of water on them from it, and their
good-humour was restored directly. For they said, it was a shame to
quarrel upon Christmas Day. And so it was! God love it, so it was!
